images.caption: Figure 1.Examples of the two mismatches in issue localization: (a) symptom–to-cause mismatch, where the issue description does not directly expose the underlying root cause; and (b) one-to-many mismatch, where resolving the issue requires modifying multiple interdependent code entities.

Figure 2.Performance of localization approaches in addressing symptom–to-cause (i.e., symptom–to-cause distance ¿ 1) and one-to-many mismatches (i.e., more than one ground-truth function). Results are averaged over issues from SWE-bench Lite, LocBench, and Multi-SWE-bench Java using Claude-3.5.

Figure 4.Illustration of CIG for issue astropy__astropy-12907 in SWE-bench Lite(Jimenez et al.,2024). Vertices represent sub-issues grounded to corresponding code entities in RDFS; edges denote probabilistic causal dependencies.

Figure 6.Generalizability across symptom-to-cause distance.
Performance decreases as the symptom-to-cause distance grows, whileGraphLocatorconsistently achieves the best results among baselines.

Figure 6.Generalizability across symptom-to-cause distance.
Performance decreases as the symptom-to-cause distance grows, whileGraphLocatorconsistently achieves the best results among baselines.

Figure 7.Generalizability across the number of involved functions.
As the number of ground-truth functions increases, performance drops for all methods, butGraphLocatorremains the most robust.
Figure 8.Time efficiency of GraphLocator and LocAgent.
Figure 8.Time efficiency of GraphLocator and LocAgent.
